text: Yeah, good question. So look, there are probably now a dozen or so researchers who have written about how to incorporate intangibles into measures of book value while they each have slightly different approaches. The common theme is that they all rely on accounting data to measure intangible assets. So to be more specific, they focus on two particular line items in the accounting statements. So first is R and D or research and development. And second is SG&A selling general administrative expenses. So SG&A is kind of a catch-all idea that captures many things of which one is sales and marketing expenses. So the idea is that R and D and SG&A are expensed rather than capitalized. And this creates a problem. For example, if I were to spend $10 million building a factory to manufacture a new drug that I developed, that capex is capitalized, it goes on my balance sheet. On the other hand, $10 million of R and D to develop the drug that I developed is considered a cost. It comes out of net income. This inconsistency means that investments in intangible capital are considered not an asset, but an expense. So led by Baruch Lev, who I mentioned just a second ago, a lot of different researchers have now decided to treat intangible investment the same way they do tangible investment. In other words, to build balance sheet assets for intellectual property and brand. Now, what they then do is to say, okay, so, you know, we had price to book, but why not take price to book plus? But when an individual pays for it, you foods get more expensive. What can we do? Okay. First, there is a pretty weak relationship between the input cost and then the output value for any intangible investment. The goal of accounting is to capture historic costs, but the exposed value of intangible investment is very uncertain. Our $10 million we spent on this new cancer drug could be worth a billion dollars or it could be worth zero. To market this new drug could go viral or it could go flop. So that's the first problem. The second one is that accounting statements basically ignore the other two intangible pillars. All CEOs claim that their people are their greatest assets, but the only disclosure they put into their 10 Ks is headcount, which of course makes no distinction between the quality of employees or what functions they're hired to do. And then finally network effects. Uber's main asset is its external network of drivers, which doesn't show up on its balance sheet. So look, when all is said and done, this means that we are forced to go beyond accounting data. And we believe that by the end of the day, we're going to be the first to go beyond accounting. By using unstructured data, we can actually measure the output as opposed to the input of the R and D investment and the quality of human capital network effects and brand. And this allows us to transcend some of these limitations.
